To understand this, we computed the cumulative distribution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>d&#964;</i>/<i>d</i><i>z</i><sub>d</sub></span> normalized to the source optical depth for a perfect survey, that is, <a name=\"FD28\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq255.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(28)</span></span>The behavior of the cumulative distribution in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD28\">28</a>) as a function of redshift is shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F6\">6</a>. We show two different sources at redshift <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>s</sub> = 2</span> and 4, considering three different angular resolutions <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0,0.6</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">1&#8242;&#8242;</span>, and modeling the deflector with both the SIS and SIE deflectors. For clarity, we do not show the case for <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span>. </p>\n<p>We first consider <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0&#8242;&#8242;</span> (shown as a black dashed line). For this case, the normalized cumulative distributions are identical for the SIS and SIE cases. Because the distributions corresponding to the different <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>s</sub></span> differ, the differential contribution to the lensing optical depth is different for the two sources. Nevertheless, for the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.6&#8242;&#8242;</span> instrumental resolution we observe that the fraction of the optical depth lost due to an increase in <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> is the same for <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>s</sub> = 2</span> and 4 for both the SIS and SIE cases. The fraction of the optical depth lost due to an increase in <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> is thus independent of redshift, or in other words, the ratio <a name=\"FD29\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq258.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(29)</span></span>is independent of the source redshift. We computed the same distribution for sources with different apparent magnitudes and found no effect of the source magnitude on the distribution in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD28\">28</a>). </p>\n<p>As a consequence, the behavior as a function of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> of the average optical depth <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i>&#10217;</span> can be computed by considering a perfect instrument and calculating the ratio in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD29\">29</a>) for a source with a randomly chosen redshift and magnitude. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S12\"></a>4.1. Effect of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span>\n</h3>\n<p>In the left panel of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F7\">7</a> we show the evolution of the average lensing optical depth <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i>&#10217;</span> as a function of the cosmological matter density parameter <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span>, assuming a flat FLRW universe and considering the finite angular resolution <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span> corresponding to the <i>Gaia </i>survey. We observe a very high dependence of the average optical depth as a function of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> with an order of magnitude difference between an empty universe and a universe full of matter (<span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub> = 0</span> and 1, respectively). For this reason, using the fraction of lensed sources in a sample of sources has been proposed by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R34\">Turner et al. (1984)</a> to constrain the value of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span>. </p>\n<p>The observed behavior agrees very well when modeling the deflectors by means of the SIS and SIE deflectors, although the SIS model always slightly overestimates the lensing optical depth. </p>\n<p>In our simulations for the SIE deflector, we observed no dependence as a function of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> of the relative fraction of lensing events on a given number of lensed images. </p>\n<p>In the right panel of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F7\">7</a> we show the expected normalized redshift distribution of the lensed sources <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq261.png\"></span> and of the deflectors <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq262.png\"></span> for the three different values of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub> = 0,0.3</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">1</span>. For the sake of clarity, we only show the deflector redshift distribution corresponding to the early-type galaxy population, but the one associated with the late-type population presents a similar behavior. As previously mentioned, the obtained normalized redshift distributions <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>s</sub></sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>d</sub></sub></span> are identical for the SIS and SIE models. To minimize the computing time, we present the distributions obtained for the SIS model case. </p>\n<p>Finally, in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F8\">8</a> we represent the normalized distribution <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub></sub></span> as a function of Einstein angle <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub></span> of the lensed sources for different values of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span>. These distributions were obtained with the help of Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD23\">23</a>). We considered the deflectors to be modeled with SIS deflectors and an angular resolution <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span> corresponding to the <i>Gaia </i>survey. We find a very small dependence of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq264.png\"></span> on the cosmological model parameter value. </p>\n<p>We also computed the normalized distribution <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq110.png\"></span> as a function of apparent magnitude <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>m</i></span> and found no effect of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span>. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F8\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-fig8_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 8</span></a><p>Effect of the cosmological matter density parameter <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> on the normalized Einstein angular radius distribution <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq264.png\"></span> of the lensed sources. We considered the deflectors to be modeled by SIS deflectors and an angular resolution <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span> corresponding to the <i>Gaia </i>survey. <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub></span> is expressed in arcsecond.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=8&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425411\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S13\"></a>5. Conclusions</h2>\n<p>Of the <span class=\"simple-math\">6.64 &#215; 10<sup>5</sup></span> QSOs that are brighter than <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i> = 20</span> to be detected in the <i>Gaia </i>survey, we expect about 2886 to be multiply imaged sources and that 450 of these are produced by a late-type galaxy. We have modeled the deflector population by means of the SIE and SIS mass distributions and found both model predictions to agree very well, although the SIS model overestimates the mean lensing optical depth by <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span><span class=\"simple-math\">10%</span>. Most of the multiply imaged sources will be composed of two images, but we expect more than 250 lensed sources with more than two lensed images detected. </p>\n<p>We expect only <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>1600 of the multiply imaged quasars to have an angular separation between their images that is large enough to be resolved from seeing-limited observations (i.e., considering a ground-based survey without an adaptive optics system), allowing the acquisition of ground-based data to complement the spectra and time series provided by the satellite, <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>80 of them having more than two lensed images detected. </p>\n<p>We showed that lenses with a deflector at high redshift tend to be missed as the angular resolution of a survey becomes worse because these events are characterized by a smaller Einstein angular radius. Thanks to its angular resolution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span>, the lensed sources discovered in the <i>Gaia </i>survey will thus provide a unique statistical sample of lensed sources from which to study the evolution effects of the deflecting galaxy population, with the detection of <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>800 lenses at a redshift between <span class=\"simple-math\">0.8</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">2</span>. </p>\n<p>We did not consider the influence of the deflector environment, which may produce an additional shear and convergence to the gravitational potential. <a name=\"InR21\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R21\">Oguri et al. (2005)</a> have shown that the additional convergence produced by the galaxy environment may increase the lensing probability (especially at large angular separation) by boosting the image separation and amplification bias, mainly driven by convergence. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R6\">Huterer et al. (2005)</a> showed that the external shear increases the fraction of quads in a sample of lensed sources. Our estimate of the number of lenses to be discovered by <i>Gaia </i>may thus slightly underestimate the lenses and quads to be discovered. We also neglected multiple deflectors at different redhshifts because the probability for such an event would be on the order of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i>&#10217;<sup>2</sup> ~ 10<sup>-5</sup></span>, which is negligible compared to the lensing probability by a single deflector. </p>\n<p>We computed the normalized redshift distributions of the lensed sources <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>s</sub></sub></span> and of the deflectors <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>d</sub></sub></span> and found that these normalized distributions are the same whether the deflectors are modeled by means of the SIS or the SIE mass distributions. The normalized deflector redshift distribution expected for the late-type galaxy population peaks at a higher redshift than that for the early-type one. </p>\n<p>Furthermore, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>s</sub></sub></span> is independent of the angular resolution of the survey. As a consequence, we conclude that the fraction of the optical depth lost by a source when increasing <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> is independent of source redshift. </p>\n<p>Finally, we analyzed the effect of the cosmological matter density parameter <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> on the average lensing optical depth and on the distributions as a function of the redshift of the lensed sources and deflectors. We conclude that all three are sensitive to the cosmological model parameter value and may be used to constrain the cosmological model. We found no effect of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> on the fraction of lensed sources as a function of the number of lensed images or on the apparent magnitude distribution of the lensed sources. </p>\n    <hr width=\"30%\" align=\"left\">\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN2\"></a><sup>1</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">\n          <a href=\"http://sci.esa.int/gaia/\" target=\"_blank\">http://sci.esa.int/gaia/</a>\n        </p>\n</div></div>\n    <h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"ref\"></a>References</h2>\n    <div id=\"content\">\n        <ol class=\"references\">\n                    <li>\n                <a name=\"R1\"></a>Browne, I. (2006)</a> and express the absolute magnitudes <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i></span> in the <i>Gaia </i><span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band as magnitudes of the continuum, with a zero point of the continuum K-correction at redshift <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 2</span>. <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i></span> is thus defined by <a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq269.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(A.1)</span></span>where <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>K</i><sub>em</sub></span> is the contribution from the emission lines and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>K</i><sub>cont<i>,z</i> = 2</sub></span> the continuum K-correction with zero point at redshift <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 2</span>. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F9\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-fig9_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. A.1</span></a><p>K-correction in the <i>Gaia </i>photometric <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band as a function of redshift. We represent the total K-correction (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>K</i></span>) with zero point of the continuum contribution at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 2</span>, the continuum contributions with zero points at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 0</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 2</span> (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>K</i><sub>cont</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>K</i><sub>cont<i>,z</i> = 2</sub></span>), and the emission line contribution (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>K</i><sub><i>em</i></sub></span>).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=9&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425411\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>To estimate the K-correction of the <i>Gaia </i>photometric <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band, we computed the correlation between the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band spectral transmission function (in terms of wavelengths) with the QSO synthetic spectrum derived from SDSS QSO spectra by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R35\">Vanden Berk et al. (2001)</a>. The synthetic spectrum ranging from 3800 to <span class=\"simple-math\">9200 &#197;</span> could not cover the entire wavelength range of the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span> filter (<span class=\"simple-math\">3210&#8722;11020 &#197;</span> in the observer comoving reference frame). Because the synthetic spectrum was well fitted by a continuum spectrum with spectral index <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub> = &#8722;0.46</span> between the Ly-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i></span> and H<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i></span> lines, and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub> = &#8722;1.58</span> for wavelengths longer than the H<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i></span> line (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R35\">Vanden Berk et al. 2001</a>), we extrapolated the synthetic spectrum toward longer wavelengths assuming a continuum spectrum with spectral index <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub> = &#8722;1.58</span>. </p>\n<p>We computed the contribution of the continuum to the K-correction assuming a break in the spectral index, considering the zero points of the K-Correction at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 0</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 2</span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>K</i><sub>cont</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>K</i><sub>cont<i>,z</i> = 2</sub></span>, respectively. The behavior of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>K</i><sub>cont<i>,z</i> = 2</sub></span> as a function of redshift is displayed in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F9\">A.1</a>. </p>\n<p>Finally, the contribution to the apparent magnitude of the emission lines <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>K</i><sub>em</sub></span> is given by <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>K</i><sub>em</sub> = <i>K</i>&#8722;<i>K</i><sub>cont<i>,z</i> = 2</sub></span>. The computed K-correction is shown as a function of redshift in  Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F9\">A.1</a>. </p>\n<p>To convert the absolute magnitudes <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub><i>i</i></sub></span> from the SDSS <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i></span>-band to the <i>Gaia </i><span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band absolute magnitude <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i></span>, we used the K-correction for the SDSS <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i></span>-band given in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R26\">Richards et al. (2006)</a>, the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band K-correction previously described, and calculated an average apparent magnitude transformation between the <i>Gaia </i><span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-magnitude and SDSS-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i></span> magnitude as follows: <a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq281.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(A.2)</span></span>where <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq282.png\"></span> is the synthetic QSO spectrum from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R35\">Vanden Berk et al. (2001)</a>, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq283.png\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq284.png\"></span> are the spectral transmission of the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i></span> bands, considering both magnitudes in the AB-magnitude system. The behavior of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq145.png\"></span> as a function of redshift is shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F10\">A.2</a>. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F10\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-fig10_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. A.2</span></a><p>Average color transformation <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq145.png\"></span> as a function of QSO redshift assuming the source spectral type to be that of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R35\">Vanden Berk et al. (2001)</a> and both magnitude systems to be AB-magnitudes.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=10&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425411\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>The absolute magnitude average transformation is given by <a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq285.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(A.3)</span></span>where <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq286.png\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq287.png\"></span> are the K-corrections in the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>- and SDSS <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i></span>-band, respectively. </p>\n      <h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"app\"></a>Appendix B:  <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>d</sub></sub></span> dependence on the deflector type</h2>\n<p>In this appendix, we demonstrate that <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>d</sub></sub></span> is independent of the deflector type under the assumption of constant deflector comoving density and a perfect instrument. For simplicity, we consider the case of deflectors modeled by an SIS mass distribution. </p>\n<p>The expression of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#964;</i><sub>SIS</sub></span> in Eq. (8) can be further developed by inserting the expression of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq289.png\"></span> which, using the definition of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub></span> in Eq. (2) and that of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#931;<sub>SIS</sub></span> in Eq. (3), may be written as <a name=\"FD33\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq290.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(B.1)</span></span>Inserting the latter expression into Eq. (8) leads to <a name=\"FD34\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq291.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(B.2)</span></span>where we defined <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq292.png\"></span>. The coefficient in brackets includes all the dependence on the parameters describing the VDFs (<span class=\"simple-math\">&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub>,<i>&#963;</i><sub>&#8727;</sub><i>,&#945;,&#946;</i></span>), which may refer to either early- or late-type galaxies. In our development, the deflector comoving density is assumed constant, therefore the VDF parameters do not depend on the redshift. </p>\n<p>We may obtain an expression for <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq294.png\"></span> by differentiating the former expression of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#964;</i><sub>SIS</sub></span> with respect to the deflector redshift <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span>. The result is <a name=\"FD35\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq295.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(B.3)</span></span>For a perfect instrument, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#964;</i><sub>SIS</sub></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq296.png\"></span> depend in an identical way on the VDF parameters, shown in the first factor of Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD34\">B.2</a>) and (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD35\">B.3</a>). Therefore, when calculating the normalized redshift  </p>\n<p>distribution of the deflectors by inserting Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD34\">B.2</a>) and (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD35\">B.3</a>) into the definition of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>d</sub></sub></span> (Eq. (18)) and using the definition of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i>&#10217;</span> (Eq. (16)), the factors containing the VDF parameters cancel each other out as long as we assume no redshift or absolute magnitude dependence of the VDF parameters. For a perfect instrument, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>d</sub></sub></span> is thus identical for early- and late-type galaxy deflectors because it does no longer depend on the parameters defining the deflector VDF (<span class=\"simple-math\">&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub>,<i>&#963;</i><sub>&#8727;</sub><i>,&#945;,</i></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i></span>). </p>\n<p>However, when the finite angular resolution of the survey is taken into account, the integration area for the lensing cross section <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>S</i><sub><i>y</i></sub></span> is now a function of the ratio <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub>/<i>&#952;</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span>, with <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq299.png\"></span>. This dependence on <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> leads to different results for the two deflector types because this parameter differs for the early- and late-type galaxy VDF. </p>\n    \n  <h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"tabs\"></a>All Tables</h2>\n<div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/T1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 1</span></a><p>Comparison of the mean lensing optical depth and the expected number of detected multiply imaged quasars for different values of the survey angular resolution corresponding to a perfect survey (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0&#8242;&#8242;</span>), <i>Gaia </i>(<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span>), and typical ground-based observations (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.6&#8242;&#8242;</span>).</p>\n<div class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#T1\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"figs\"></a>All Figures</h2>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-fig1_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 1</span></a><p>Luminosity function as a function of the absolute magnitude <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub><i>i</i></sub></span> in the SDSS <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i></span>-band for different redshift bins. In both panels we indicate the typical value of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> for the <i>Gaia </i>survey and typical seeing-limited ground-based observations.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=4&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425411\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F4\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-fig5_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 5</span></a><p><i>Left</i>: expected normalized distributions <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i></span> as a function of the redshift of the lensed sources (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>s</sub></span>) and of the deflectors (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>d</sub></span>). For comparison, we also include the normalized redshift distribution of the sources (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub>QSO</sub></span>). The simulations were made assuming <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span>. We indicate the median value of each distribution (<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq215.png\"></span>, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq216.png\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq217.png\"></span>). <i>Right</i>: normalized distribution <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq110.png\"></span> of the lensed sources as a function of the apparent magnitude. For comparison, we show the DNCF as a function of the magnitude of all the detected sources, normalized by <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>N</i><sub>QSO</sub>/ &#937;<sub><i>Gaia</i></sub></span>.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=5&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425411\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F5\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-fig6_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 6</span></a><p><i>Left</i>: normalized redshift distribution of the deflectors <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq231.png\"></span> and its cumulative representation for three different values of the angular resolution <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0,0.2</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">0.6&#8242;&#8242;</span>. <i>Right</i>: cumulative distribution <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#964;</i><sup>-1</sup>d<i>&#964;</i></span>/d<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> as a function of the lens redshift. "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2016A&A...590A..42F", "Tables status": "Complete", "Inspection status": "Complete", "Paper Overview": {"abstract": "<BR /> Aims: We report a study on the statistical properties of the multiply imaged quasi-stellar objects (QSOs) to be detected within the Gaia survey. <BR /> Methods: We considered two types of potential deflectors, the singular isothermal sphere (SIS) and the singular isothermal ellipsoid (SIE), to estimate the number of multiply imaged quasars as well as the normalized distributions of the redshifts of the lensed sources and of their associated deflectors. We also investigated the distribution of the lensing events as a function of their angular size and apparent magnitude. We compared the Gaia survey for multiply imaged quasars to typical ground-based surveys and to an ideal survey that would be carried out with a perfect instrument from space. <BR /> Results: Of the 6.64 \u00d7 10<SUP>5</SUP> QSOs brighter than G = 20 to be detected by Gaia, we expect the discovery of about 2886 multiply imaged sources, 450 of which are expected to be produced by a late-type galaxy. We expect only ~1600 of these multiply imaged quasars to have an angular separation between their images that is large enough to be resolved from seeing-limited observations, and ~80 of them to have more than two lensed images.", "start_page": "A42", "authors": ["Finet, F.", "Surdej, J."], "issn": "0004-6361", "Title": "Multiply imaged quasi-stellar objects in the Gaia survey", "type_of_reference": "JOUR", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "quasars: general", "cosmological parameters"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2016A&A...590A..42F", "journal_name": "Astronomy and Astrophysics", "volume": "590", "publication_year": "2016/05/1", "doi": "10.1051/0004-6361/201425411", "author_address": ["AA(Extragalactic Astrophysics and Space Observations (AEOS), Institut d'Astrophysique et de G\u00e9ophysique, Li\u00e8ge University, All\u00e9e du 6 Ao\u00fbt, 17 (Sart Tilman, B\u00e2t. Transitional//EN\">\n\n<div class=\"menu\" id=\"bloc\"><ul>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#top_full\">Top</a></li>\n<li><a Mathematical formalism ...</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#S8\">3. Observational constraints</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#S11\">4. Conclusions</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#ref\">References</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#app\">Appendix A:</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#tabs\">List of tables</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#figs\">List of figures</a></li>\n</ul></div>\n<div id=\"contenu\">\n<a name=\"top_full\"></a><div id=\"head\">A&amp;A 590, A42 (2016)<h2 class=\"title\">Multiply imaged quasi-stellar objects in the <i>Gaia </i>survey</h2>\n<div class=\"article-authors\"><p class=\"bold\"><span id=\"aa25411-14-author-1\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201425411&amp;n=1\" class=\"author\">F. Finet</span><sup>1</sup><sup>,2</sup> and <span id=\"aa25411-14-author-2\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201425411&amp;n=2\" class=\"author\">J. Surdej</span><sup>1</sup></p></div>\n<p class=\"aff\"><sup>1</sup> Extragalactic Astrophysics and Space Observations (AEOS), Institut d&#8217;Astrophysique et de G&#233;ophysique, Li&#232;ge University, All&#233;e du 6 Ao&#251;t, 17 (Sart Tilman, B&#226;t. B5c),  4000   Li&#232;ge,  Belgium \n<br><sup>2</sup>  National Astronomical Observatory of Japan (NAOJ), 650 N. A&#8217;ohoku Place,  Hilo,  96720   HI,  USA \n<br>\n            e-mail: finet@naoj.org\n            \n          <br></p>\n<p class=\"history\"><span class=\"bold\">Received: </span>26 November 2014<br><span class=\"bold\">Accepted: </span>9 October 2015</p>\n<p class=\"bold\"><a name=\"abs\"></a>Abstract</p>\n        <p><i>Aims. </i>We report a study on the statistical properties of the multiply imaged quasi-stellar objects (QSOs) to be detected within the <i>Gaia </i>survey.</p>\n        <p><i>Methods. </i>We considered two types of potential deflectors, the singular isothermal sphere (SIS) and the singular isothermal ellipsoid (SIE), to estimate the number of multiply imaged quasars as well as the normalized distributions of the redshifts of the lensed sources and of their associated deflectors. We also investigated the distribution of the lensing events as a function of their angular size and apparent magnitude. We compared the <i>Gaia </i>survey for multiply imaged quasars to typical ground-based surveys and to an ideal survey that would be carried out with a perfect instrument from space.</p>\n        <p><i>Results. </i>Of the <span class=\"simple-math\">6.64 &#215; 10<sup>5</sup></span> QSOs brighter than <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i> = 20</span> to be detected by <i>Gaia</i>, we expect the discovery of about 2886 multiply imaged sources, 450 of which are expected to be produced by a late-type galaxy. We expect only <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>1600 of these multiply imaged quasars to have an angular separation between their images that is large enough to be resolved from seeing-limited observations, and <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>80 of them to have more than two lensed images.</p>\n      <div class=\"kword\"><p><span class=\"bold\">Key words: </span>gravitational lensing: strong / quasars: general / cosmological parameters</p></div>\n</div>\n<p><i>&#169; ESO, 2016</i></p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S1\"></a>1. Introduction</h2>\n<p>The <i>Gaia </i>mission<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FN2\">1</a></sup> is currently conducting an all-sky coverage for a total duration of five years. The satellite is equipped with three different instruments: an astrometric instrument, a radial velocity spectrometer, and a photometric instrument. The latter produces two low-resolution spectra in the blue and the red, from which the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i><sub>BS</sub></span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i><sub>RS</sub></span>, and the global <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band magnitudes are derived (see <a name=\"InR8\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R8\">Jordi et al. 2006</a>, <a name=\"InR9\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R9\">2010</a> for the description of the photometric system). The survey is expected to be complete down to the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band magnitude <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i> = 20</span>. </p>\n<p>The main goal of the mission is to make a three-dimensional map of our Galaxy based on measurements of the photometry, astrometry, and proper motion of <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span><span class=\"simple-math\">10<sup>9</sup></span> stars. Radial velocity measurements will be obtained for a subsample of brighter objects. The satellite is also expected to detect a very large number of extragalactic objects, some of which will be quasi-stellar objects (QSOs). The detection of QSOs will be difficult at low Galactic latitudes (<span class=\"simple-math\">|<i>b</i>| &lt; 25&#8722;30&#176;</span>). Judging from the QSO detection in the remaining 60% of the sky, this will probably lead to the detection of <span class=\"simple-math\">5.5&#8722;7 &#215; 10<sup>5</sup></span> QSOs (<a name=\"InR17\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R17\">Mignard 2012</a>; <a name=\"InR27\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R27\">Robin et al. 2012</a>; <a name=\"InR32\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R32\">Slezak 2007</a>). This very large sample, in combination with the astrometry precision of the survey of down to <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>25 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>-as, will lead to the direct construction of a new celestial reference frame in the optical that is at least a hundred times denser than the international celestial reference frame (ICRF), which will enable testing general relativity (<a name=\"InR15\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R15\">Mignard 2005</a>). We expect that multiply imaged QSOs are detected among these sources through gravitational lensing by foreground-deflecting galaxies, which could be detected down to an angular separation of <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span><span class=\"simple-math\">0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span> (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R17\">Mignard 2012</a>). </p>\n<p>Imaging with <i>Gaia </i>is made by reconstructing 2D-images from multiple 1D-drift scan images acquired in different directions (<a name=\"InR5\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R5\">Harrison 2011</a>). As a result of the peculiar drift-scan imaging mode of <i>Gaia</i>, it is necessary to properly estimate the properties of the lensed population of QSOs to define a detection strategy for the lensing events. The statistical properties of the QSOs to be detected have been studied by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R32\">Slezak (2007)</a>. In this paper we concentrate on studying the expected statistical properties of the population of lensed QSOs. This information will be used to define the best strategy for detecting these lensing events throughout the different scans generated by the satellite. </p>\n<p>Because of the very large number of sources detected by <i>Gaia</i>, we expect the gravitational lenses to constitute an unprecedentedly large sample. In addition to the scientific interest of each individual lensed source, these multiply imaged sources will constitute a statistical sample that may be used to constrain the cosmological mass density parameter <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> through the statistics of gravitational lensing in the sample, and the lensed sources will also be used to study the evolution in the population of deflecting galaxies. </p>\n<p>A previous rough estimation of the number of expected gravitational lenses in the <i>Gaia </i>mission has already been performed (<a name=\"InR4\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R4\">Finet et al. 2012</a>), and <a name=\"InR16\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R16\">Mignard (2008)</a> has studied the effect of gravitational lensing on the reference frame constituted by the sources. We here report an in-depth study of their expected statistical properties. </p>\n<p>We introduce the mathematical formalism in the next section. We first derive an expression for the probability of a source to be lensed, alternatively modeling the deflectors by spherical (Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#S4\">2.1.1</a>) and elliptical (Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#S5\">2.1.2</a>) singular isothermal mass distributions. We then introduce in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#S6\">2.2</a> the joint probability distribution of the <i>Gaia </i>QSOs in the redshift-absolute magnitude plane that we use in the next subsections to calculate various expected distributions of astrophysical parameters linked to the lensed population. Specifically, the average lensing optical depth in the sample and the redshift distributions of the lensed sources and of the deflectors are derived. Finally, we derive an expression for the distributions of the lensed sources as a function of their apparent magnitude and the angular separation between the lensed images. </p>\n<p>In Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#S8\">3</a> we present the observational data on which we base our simulations, we derive the best-fit parameter for the QSO luminosity function (LF) evolution models, based on the LF of <a name=\"InR26\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R26\">Richards et al. (2006)</a> and <a name=\"InR23\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R23\">Palanque-Delabrouille et al. (2013)</a>, from which we infer the joint probability density of the sources for simulation purposes. Finally, in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#S11\">4</a> we present the results of the simulations and study the effect of the cosmological mass density parameter <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> and that of the smallest angular separation resolvable in the survey. The latter is done by comparing the results for a perfect instrument, the <i>Gaia </i>observatory, and typical ground-based surveys. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S2\"></a>2. Mathematical formalism for gravitational-lensing statistics</h2>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S3\"></a>2.1. Lensing optical depth</h3>\n<p>Multiple images of a background source arise when a foreground galaxy is located close enough to the source line of sight. In the present work, the sources considered are point-like QSOs. To calculate the probability for a source to be lensed as a result of a foreground deflector near its line of sight, it is therefore crucial to accurately model the volume density of the potential deflecting galaxies. The comoving volume density of deflectors with a line-of-sight velocity dispersion in the range <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span> to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i> + d<i>&#963;</i></span> is given by the velocity dispersion function (VDF) <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq16.png\"></span>, which is modeled by the modified Schechter function (<a name=\"InR31\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R31\">Sheth et al. 2003</a>; <a name=\"InR18\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R18\">Mitchell et al. 2005</a>; <a name=\"InR3\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R3\">Choi et al. 2007</a>; <a name=\"InR2\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R2\">Chae 2010</a>) <a name=\"FD1\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq17.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(1)</span></span>where <span class=\"simple-math\">&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> are the characteristic volume density and line-of-sight velocity dispersion, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i></span> are the VDF slope at low and high <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;,</i></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq23.png\"></span> is the complete gamma function. </p>\n<p>Thanks to their larger mass, early-type galaxies are more efficient deflectors than late-type galaxies, which tend to form lensed images with a smaller angular separation. The latter, although more numerous, were shown to constitute typically less than 10% of the lensing events in a flux limited sample from ground-based observations (<a name=\"InR10\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R10\">Keeton et al. 1998</a>; <a name=\"InR11\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R11\">Kochanek et al. 2000</a>). Nevertheless, the fraction of lensing events that is due to late-type galaxies increases with a better angular resolution of the survey (e.g., the CLASS survey where <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span><span class=\"simple-math\">25%</span> of the lenses are due to spiral galaxies, cf. <a name=\"InR1\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R1\">Browne et al. 2003</a>). Therefore, thanks to the very good angular resolution of the <i>Gaia </i>survey, we expect late-type galaxies to contribute to a significant fraction of the lensed sources. In our simulations, we consider the population of deflectors to be formed by both early- and late-type galaxies. </p>\n<p>Most of the lensing statistics studies of the evolution with redshift of the deflector population are consistent with a no-evolution scenario or very small effect of the evolution (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R2\">Chae 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR22\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R22\">Oguri et al. 2012</a>). For our estimation we thus neglected the evolution effect in the deflector galaxy VDF and used the value of the VDF parameters measured in the local Universe by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R3\">Choi et al. (2007)</a>, that is, for early-type galaxies <span class=\"simple-math\">&#934;<sub>&#8727; ,E</sub> = 8 &#215; 10<sup>-3</sup><i>h</i><sup>3</sup> Mpc<sup>-3</sup></span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sub>&#8727; ,E</sub> = 161km s<sup>-1</sup></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">(<i>&#945;</i><sub>E</sub>,<i>&#946;</i><sub>E</sub>) = (2.32,2.67)</span>, and for late-type galaxies <span class=\"simple-math\">&#934;<sub>&#8727; ,L</sub> = 66 &#215; 10<sup>-3</sup><i>h</i><sup>3</sup> Mpc<sup>-3</sup></span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sub>&#8727; ,L</sub> = 91.5km s<sup>-1</sup></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">(<i>&#945;</i><sub>L</sub>,<i>&#946;</i><sub>L</sub>) = (0.69,2.10)</span>. </p>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S4\"></a>2.1.1. Singular isothermal sphere deflector</h4>\n<p>As a first approximation, the total mass distribution of early- and late-type galaxies is well modeled by means of the singular isothermal sphere (SIS) profile, that is, by a spherically symmetric mass distribution with a volume density scaling as <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8733;</span><span class=\"simple-math\"><i>r</i><sup>-2</sup></span>, where <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>r</i></span> is the distance to the deflector center (see, e.g., <a name=\"InR12\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R12\">Koopmans et al. 2006</a>, <a name=\"InR13\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R13\">2009</a> for an observational confirmation of the almost isothermal behavior of the galaxy mass distribution). Such a deflector may lead to the formation of at most two lensed images of a background source, with an angular separation equal to twice the Einstein ring angular radius <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub></span>, which is given by <a name=\"FD2\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq35.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(2)</span></span>where <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>D</i><sub>ds</sub></span> (respectively <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>D</i><sub>os</sub></span>) is the angular diameter distance between the deflector (respectively the observer) and the source, and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>c</i></span> is the speed of light. </p>\n<p>A deflector located in the deflector plane (perpendicular to the source line of sight) at a redshift <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>d</sub></span> will lead to the formation of multiple images of a source at redshift <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>s</sub></span> with apparent magnitude <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>m</i></span> if it is located inside an area <span class=\"simple-math\">&#931;<sub>SIS</sub></span> called the lensing cross section, which is centered on the projected source position and is defined by (<a name=\"InR34\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R34\">Turner et al. 1984</a>) <a name=\"FD3\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq43.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(3)</span></span>where <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>D</i><sub>od</sub></span> is the angular diameter distance between the observer <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>o</i></span> and the deflector <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>d</i></span>. We have introduced the coordinates <span class=\"simple-math\"><b><i>y</i></b> = (<i>y</i><sub>1</sub>,<i>y</i><sub>2</sub>)</span>, the projection on the deflector plane of the source position, normalized to the scale factor <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>D</i><sub>od</sub><i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub></span>, that is, the Einstein radius. </p>\n<p>The amplification bias <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>B</i>(<i>m,</i><b><i>y</i></b>)</span> is introduced to take into account the favorable bias in the calculation of the source lensing optical depth, which arises because of the flux amplification in the lensing event, which for instance leads to the inclusion in flux-limited samples of sources that are intrinsically fainter. In our simulations, we estimated the amplification bias by means of the source differential number counts function (DNCF) <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq50.png\"></span> as a function of their apparent magnitude <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>m</i></span>, through the relation<a name=\"FD4\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq51.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(4)</span></span>where <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>A</i>(<b><i>y</i></b>)</span> is the total amplification of the lensing event, that is, the sum of the multiple image amplification moduli. </p>\n<p>The integration area <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>S</i><sub><i>y</i></sub></span> in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD3\">3</a>) represents the area (normalized to the scale factor) in which the presence of a deflector leads to the formation of a lensing event, defined as the detection of two lensed images by the survey strategy. Depending on the survey angular resolution, the associated 2D integration interval <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>S</i><sub><i>y</i></sub></span> varies, and so does the lensing cross section. </p>\n<p>The probability <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq54.png\"></span> for a source with a redshift <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>s</sub></span> and an apparent magnitude <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>m</i></span> to be multiply imaged, or the lensing optical depth, is obtained by integrating the density of deflectors (over all possible values of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span>) located within the envelope of the lensing cross sections at each intermediate redshift <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span>, defined as the lensing volume (<a name=\"InR19\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R19\">Nemiroff 1989</a>). This leads to the expression <a name=\"FD5\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq56.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(5)</span></span>where <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span> is in the range <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sub>1</sub></span> to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sub>2</sub></span> associated with the deflector population, and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>c</i></span>d<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i></span>/d<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> is the infinitesimal light-distance element, which in a flat FLRW universe is expressed as (<a name=\"InR24\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R24\">Peebles 1993</a>) <a name=\"FD6\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq60.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(6)</span></span>where <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> is the present-day value of the cosmological mass density parameter. The integration over <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span> in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD5\">5</a>) may be performed analytically under the assumption of a non-evolving deflector population. Using Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD2\">2</a>) and (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD3\">3</a>), <span class=\"simple-math\">&#931;<sub>SIS</sub></span> may be expressed as <a name=\"FD7\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq61.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(7)</span></span>where <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq62.png\"></span>. Inserting the latter expression into Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD5\">5</a>) and integrating over the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span> range <span class=\"simple-math\">[<i>&#963;</i><sub>1</sub>,<i>&#963;</i><sub>2</sub>[ &#8594; [0, + &#8734;[</span>, we obtain <a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq64.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(8)</span></span></p>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S5\"></a>2.1.2. Singular isothermal ellipsoid deflector</h4>\n<p>To reproduce lensing configurations with more than two lensed images, as observed among the known gravitational lens systems, a new model was introduced by <a name=\"InR14\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R14\">Kormann et al. (1994)</a>: the singular isothermal ellipsoid (SIE). This model introduces an internal ellipticity into the mass distribution, which is characterized by the axis ratio <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i></span> between the axes of the projected mass distribution on the deflector plane. The SIE mass profile may produce two, three (cusp configuration), or four lensed images depending on the position of the source relative to the caustics (defined as the lines of infinite amplification in the source plane). Non-singular mass profiles may produce an additional highly deamplified central lensed image, which is difficult to detect because it is very faint and dimmed by dust extinction in the deflector. Because this central lensed image is not likely to be detected in the <i>Gaia </i>images, we here only consider the lensed images produced by the SIE model that are effectively detected on the CCD frames. </p>\n<p>When considering an SIE deflector, the lensing cross section in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD3\">3</a>) now depends on the deflector axis ratio. We may define a lensing event as the detection of multiple images or as the detection of a given number <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i></span> of lensed images (two, three, or four), regardless of whether we account for the ability of the instrument to resolve lensed images with a too small angular separation. Consequently, depending on the definition of the lensing event, the area <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>S</i><sub><i>y</i></sub></span> in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD3\">3</a>) varies, and we therefore define different cross sections: <span class=\"simple-math\">&#931;<sub>SIE</sub></span> corresponds to the detection of multiple images irrespective of their number, and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#931;<sub>SIE<i>,i</i></sub></span> to the detection of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i></span> lensed images. </p>\n<p>The volume density of the deflectors is now also a function of the axis ratio <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i></span>. Because of the lack of observational constraints on the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i>&#8722;<i>&#963;</i></span> correlation for the deflectors, we assume that the distribution of the axis ratio is independent of the deflector line-of-sight velocity dispersion. The number density of deflectors with a line-of-sight velocity dispersion and axis ratio in the range <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span> to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i> + d<i>&#963;</i></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i></span> to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i> + d<i>q</i></span>, respectively, is thus <a name=\"FD9\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq71.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(9)</span></span>where <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>n</i><sub><i>q</i></sub>(<i>q</i>)</span> is the normalized distribution as a function of the axis ratio <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i></span> for early- or late-type galaxies, and where the deflector VDF <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq16.png\"></span> is given by Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD1\">1</a>). </p>\n<p><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R12\">Koopmans et al. (2006)</a> and <a name=\"InR33\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R33\">Sluse et al. (2012)</a> have independently confirmed through studying various gravitational lens samples that elliptical galaxy isophotes and the isodensity curves of their projected mass distribution have well-correlated ellipticities and major-axis directions. The normalized distribution <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>n</i><sub><i>q</i></sub>(<i>q</i>)</span> can thus be estimated from the distribution of the isophotes of early-type galaxies as measured by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R3\">Choi et al. (2007)</a> in the local Universe. </p>\n<p>To calculate the lensing optical depth <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq74.png\"></span> for a source with deflectors modeled by SIE mass profiles, we need to integrate over both variables <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i></span> (<a name=\"InR6\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R6\">Huterer et al. 2005</a>), which leads to <a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq75.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(10)</span></span>The integration over <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span> can be performed using Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD7\">7</a>) while adopting the same assumptions as for the SIS case. This leads to <a name=\"FD11\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq76.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(11)</span></span>We have developed software toolboxes using <i>Matlab</i>, allowing us to calculate the lensing cross sections and optical depths by modeling the deflectors by means of both the SIS and the SIE mass distribution (Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD3\">3</a>), (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD5\">5</a>), and (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD11\">11</a>)). </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S6\"></a>2.2. QSO joint probability density d<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq77.png\"></span>\n</h3>\n<p>The sources detected in a survey are characterized by their absolute magnitude <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i></span> and their redshift <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>s</sub></span>. Each source has a probability <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq79.png\"></span> to be detected with a redshift and an absolute magnitude in the ranges <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>s</sub></span> to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>s</sub> + d<i>z</i><sub>s</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i></span> to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i> + d<i>M</i></span>, respectively. Furthermore, we may define the joint probability density <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq82.png\"></span> associated with <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq79.png\"></span> by means of the relation <a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq83.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(12)</span></span>For an already existing survey, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq82.png\"></span> may be estimated from the normalized smoothed histogram in the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq84.png\"></span> plane of the detected sources. However, for prospective simulation purposes, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq82.png\"></span> can be estimated by means of the QSO luminosity function <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq85.png\"></span> (<a name=\"InR20\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R20\">Oguri &amp; Marshall 2010</a>) by means of the relation <a name=\"FD13\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq86.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(13)</span></span>where</p>\n<p>\n          <ul>\n            <li>\n              <p>\n                <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq87.png\"></span>\n                 accounts for selection biases in the \n                <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq84.png\"></span>\n                 plane, which occur during the detection procedure of the sources. For a perfect flux-limited\n                 sample, this function equals one in the region ofthe\n                <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq84.png\"></span>\n                 plane which leads to an apparent magnitude brighterthan\n                 the survey limiting magnitude. \n              </p>\n            </li>\n            <li>\n              <p>\n                <span class=\"simple-math\">\n                  <i>N</i>\n                  <sub>QSO</sub>\n                </span>\n                 is the total number of QSOs detected within the survey; \n              </p>\n            </li>\n            <li>\n              <p>\n                 d\n                <span class=\"simple-math\">\n                  <i>V</i>\n                  <sub>c</sub>\n                </span>/d\n                <span class=\"simple-math\">\n                  <i>z</i>\n                </span>\n                 is the differential contribution at redshift \n                <span class=\"simple-math\">\n                  <i>z</i>\n                </span>\n                 to the total comoving volume accessible by the survey, which in a flat expanding FLRW universe may be expressed as \n                <a name=\"FD14\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq90.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(14)</span></span>\n                <b>where </b>\n                <span class=\"simple-math\">\n                  <i>D</i>\n                  <sub>c</sub>\n                </span>\n                <b> is the line-of-sight comoving distance at redshift </b>\n                <span class=\"simple-math\">\n                  <i>z</i>\n                </span>\n                <b>, </b>\n                <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq92.png\"></span>\n                 its differential contribution, and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub><i>Gaia</i></sub></span>\n                 is the solid angle covered by the survey in which QSO detection is possible. \n              </p>\n            </li>\n          </ul>\n        </p>\n<p>The joint probability density <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>d</i><sub>obs</sub>(<i>z</i><sub><i>z</i></sub><i>,M</i>)</span> is closely related to observable distributions of the source population. Indeed, the marginal distribution <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq95.png\"></span> obtained by integrating <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq82.png\"></span> over <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i></span> is the normalized redshift distribution of the sources. Similarly, the differential number counts function (DNCF) as a function of the apparent magnitude may be estimated by <a name=\"FD15\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq96.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(15)</span></span>where <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq97.png\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq98.png\"></span> are the distance modulus and K-correction at redshift <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>s</sub></span>, respectively. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S7\"></a>2.3. Source statistical properties</h3>\n<p>The joint probability density of the source population is directly linked to the distribution of the sources in the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq99.png\"></span> plane and to their observable distributions <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>n</i><sub><i>z</i></sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>n</i><sub><i>m</i></sub></span>. It may be used as a weighting factor to estimate the mathematical expectation of any function of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>s</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i></span>. </p>\n<p>We assume that we have an expression for the lensing optical depth <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq102.png\"></span> as a function of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>s</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i></span> for a given source. This expression is trivially obtained from <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq54.png\"></span>, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq74.png\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq103.png\"></span> (Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD5\">5</a>) and (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD11\">11</a>)) considering <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq104.png\"></span>. Its mathematical expectation <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i>&#10217;</span> is simply given by <a name=\"FD16\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq106.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(16)</span></span>where <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i>&#10217;</span> represents the fraction of sources in the detected population to have undergone a gravitational lensing event. </p>\n<p>Similarly, the expected normalized redshift distribution of the deflectors <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq107.png\"></span> is given by (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R22\">Oguri et al. 2012</a>) <a name=\"FD17\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq108.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(17)</span></span>and the expected normalized redshift distribution of the lensed sources by (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R20\">Oguri &amp; Marshall 2010</a>) <a name=\"FD18\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq109.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(18)</span></span>By integrating over the source redshift, we may also derive the normalized distribution <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq110.png\"></span> as a function of the apparent magnitude <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>m</i></span> of the lensed sources <a name=\"FD19\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq111.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(19)</span></span>Finally, we define the normalized probability density <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub></sub></span> of observing a gravitational lens system with an angular configuration <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub></span> in the lensed population. From the definition of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub></span> in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD2\">2</a>), we may trivially derive the following relations <a name=\"FD20\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq113.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(20)</span></span>where <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq114.png\"></span>. Furthermore, from the definition of the lensing cross section in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD3\">3</a>), we have <a name=\"FD21\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq115.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(21)</span></span>where <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq116.png\"></span> is the lensing cross section evaluated for the typical value of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub> = <i>&#952;</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span>. Inserting Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD20\">20</a>) and (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD21\">21</a>) in the definition of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#964;</i><sub>SIS</sub></span> in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD5\">5</a>) and making use of Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD1\">1</a>), we may derive the expression of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#964;</i><sub>SIS</sub></span> for which the integration is done over <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub></span> rather than <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span>. Deriving this expression with respect to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub></span>, we find <a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq119.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(22)</span></span>The normalized probability density <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub></sub></span> is then simply obtained by averaging the previous expression over the detected population of sources <a name=\"FD23\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq120.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(23)</span></span>Using the joint probability density <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq82.png\"></span> as a weighting factor to average quantities over the entire population of sources detected in the survey, we have derived expressions for the mean optical depth <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i>&#10217;</span> (Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD16\">16</a>)), and of the normalized redshift distributions expected for the deflectors <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>d</sub></sub></span> (Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD17\">17</a>)) and for the lensed sources <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>s</sub></sub></span> (Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD18\">18</a>)). We also derived the normalized distributions <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i></span> as a function of the apparent magnitude <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>m</i></span> and Einstein angle <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub></span> of the lensed sources (Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD19\">19</a>) and (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD23\">23</a>), respectively). </p>\n<p>The fundamental quantity needed is the joint probability density <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq82.png\"></span> corresponding to the expected <i>Gaia </i>survey sources, which we estimate in the next section. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S8\"></a>3. Observational constraints</h2>\n<p>In this section, we describe the observational constraints used to estimate the joint probability density <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq124.png\"></span> for the <i>Gaia </i>survey. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S9\"></a>3.1. QSO luminosity function</h3>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-fig1_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 1</span></a><p>Luminosity function as a function of the absolute magnitude <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub><i>i</i></sub></span> in the SDSS <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i></span>-band for different redshift bins. We have included the LF determined by <a name=\"InR25\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R25\">Richards et al.
