For the conversion from <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub><i>g</i></sub></span> to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub><i>i</i></sub></span>, we follow <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R28\">Ross et al. (2013)</a> and convert through<a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq130.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(24)</span></span>This transformation is derived assuming the continuum to be a single power-law with a spectral index <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub> = &#8722;0.5</span>, which they used to define the continuum. </p>\n<p>The derived binned luminosity functions from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R26\">Richards et al. (2006)</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R23\">Palanque-Delabrouille et al. (2013)</a> are depicted in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F1\">1</a>, both expressed as a function of the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub><i>i</i></sub></span> magnitudes for the different redshift bins. <a name=\"InR30\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R30\">Shen &amp; Kelly (2012)</a> have also derived the QSO LF from the SDSS-DR7 in the same redshift and apparent ranges as <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R26\">Richards et al. (2006)</a> and their results agree very well. We used the result from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R26\">Richards et al. (2006)</a> because the redshift bins are similar to those of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R23\">Palanque-Delabrouille et al. (2013)</a>. </p>\n<p>We followed <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R26\">Richards et al. (2006)</a> and used absolute magnitudes <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i></span> of the continuum, with a zero point of the continuum K-correction at redshift <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 2</span>. We determined the K-correction for the <i>Gaia </i><span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band using the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band spectral transmission function (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R9\">Jordi et al. 2010</a>) with the QSO synthetic spectrum derived by <a name=\"InR35\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R35\">Vanden Berk et al. (2001)</a> from SDSS QSO spectra. We define the continuum absolute magnitude and derive the <i>Gaia </i><span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band K-correction in Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#APP1\">A</a>. </p>\n<p>To facilitate the comparison with previous results, we determined the LF evolution considering absolute magnitudes <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub><i>i</i></sub></span> in the SDSS <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i></span>-band. We converted the absolute magnitudes <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub><i>i</i></sub></span> to the <i>Gaia </i><span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band absolute magnitude <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i></span> using the transformation law derived in Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#APP1\">A</a>, based on the QSO spectrum from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R35\">Vanden Berk et al. (2001)</a>, the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band K-correction previously described, and SDSS <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i></span>-band K-correction given in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R26\">Richards et al. (2006)</a>. </p>\n<p>To model the LF, we used the conventional double power-law form for the QSO LF in terms of absolute magnitudes <a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq132.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(25)</span></span>where <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub></span> are the characteristic absolute magnitude and number density, respectively, and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i></span> are the bright and faint end slopes of the LF, respectively. </p>\n<p>For the slope parameters, we considered <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i> = &#8722;1.45</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i> = &#8722;3.31</span> (values taken from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R25\">Richards et al. 2005</a> from the analysis of the combined SDSS and 2dF samples) over the entire redshift range. </p>\n<p>We first fit the combined data in each redshift bin assuming constant slope parameters <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i></span>, fitting <span class=\"simple-math\">&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> without any evolution model constraints on their behavior as a function of the redshift. The resulting LF is shown as a dashed light gray curve in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F1\">1</a>, and the values of the best-fit parameters are shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F2\">2</a> as light gray circles for the different redshift bins. The rather large error bars arise because <span class=\"simple-math\">&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> are highly correlated. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 2</span></a><p>Behavior of the LF <span class=\"simple-math\">&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> parameters as a function of the QSO redshift. The dark continuous line shows the fit model used in our simulations. The light gray markers show the best fit parameters for <span class=\"simple-math\">&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> when fitting the LF separately in each redshift bin, without any evolution model constraints. When constraining the evolution of the characteristic density, the best parameters are found to be <span class=\"simple-math\">log&#8201;&#934;<sub>&#8727; ,low<i>z</i></sub> = &#8722;5.85</span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub></sub> = &#8722;0.77 &#177; 0.31,</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>ref</sub> = 2.09 &#177; 0.28</span>.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=2&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425411\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>Following the results of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R28\">Ross et al. (2013)</a>, we assumed that <span class=\"simple-math\">log&#8201;&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub></span> is constant for <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i>&lt; 2.05</span> (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i>&lt; 2.2</span> in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R28\">Ross et al. 2013</a>) and that it can be fitted as linearly evolving for higher <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span>. We thus assumed an evolution model for <span class=\"simple-math\">&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub></span> given by <a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq141.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(26)</span></span>In each redshift bin we then fit the value of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> for each <span class=\"simple-math\">&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub></span> given by the model. The best-fit parameters are <span class=\"simple-math\">log&#8201;&#934;<sub>&#8727; ,low<i>z</i></sub> = &#8722;5.85</span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub></sub> = &#8722;0.77 &#177; 0.31,</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>ref</sub> = 2.09 &#177; 0.28</span>. </p>\n<p>The behavior of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub></span> as a function of the redshift is shown in the lower panel of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F2\">2</a>, and the corresponding fitted values of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> are shown as dark gray markers on the upper panel. </p>\n<p>Finally, motivated by the smooth redshift evolution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span>, we fit the evolution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> by a third-order polynomial. The fit is shown in the upper panel of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F2\">2</a>. The best-fit parameters are <span class=\"simple-math\">[<i>c</i><sub>3</sub>,<i>c</i><sub>2</sub>,<i>c</i><sub>1</sub>,<i>c</i><sub>0</sub>] = [&#8722;0.0427,0.5484,&#8722;2.7563,&#8722;22.8766]</span>. </p>\n<p>The final evolution model used for <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">log&#8201;&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub></span> are shown as a function of the redshift, as a continuous dark gray line in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F2\">2</a>. The corresponding LF is represented for the different redshift bins in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F1\">1</a> as a continuous dark gray line. We represent for each redshift bin the faintest sources detectable by <i>Gaia </i>assuming <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i> = 20</span> is the faintest magnitude achievable. The limit is shown as a vertical light gray dash-dotted line. The conversion from <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span> to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub><i>i</i></sub></span> is made using the color <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq145.png\"></span> evolution as a function of the redshift, described in Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#APP1\">A</a>, while adopting the SDSS <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i></span>-band K-correction. </p>\n<p>In the range accessible to the <i>Gaia </i>mission, our LF evolution model fits the data over the entire redshift range very well. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S10\"></a>3.2. Joint probability density</h3>\n<p>To estimate the joint probability density <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq82.png\"></span> for the <i>Gaia </i>survey, we used the QSO-LF function derived in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#S9\">3.1</a> to compute <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq82.png\"></span> through Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD13\">13</a>). </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F3\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-fig3_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 3</span></a><p><i>Left</i>: joint probability density <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq82.png\"></span> for the <i>Gaia </i>sources, derived using the LF evolution model described in the text. <i>Right</i>: DNCF as a function of the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band magnitude. We use a combined observational sample of the SDSS-DR3 and 2QZ/6QZ for magnitudes brighter (fainter) than <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i> ~ 19</span>, converted to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band magnitudes and thus assuming the DNCF shape in <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band to be similar. We also show the fit used to estimate the DNCF.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=3&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425411\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-fig4_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 4</span></a><p><i>Left</i>: average lensing optical depth as a function of the survey angular resolution <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> for early- and late-type galaxy deflectors. We modeled the deflectors as SIS (<span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i><sub>SIS</sub>&#10217;</span>-continuous black line) and SIE mass distributions (<span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i><sub>SIE</sub>&#10217;</span>-continuous gray line). In the latter case, we also show the average optical depth with detection of two lensed images (<span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i><sub>SIE,2</sub>&#10217;</span> &#8211; dashed gray line). <i>Right</i>: fraction of lensed sources detected with three (light gray) or four (dark gray) lensed images as a function of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span>. The results for the case of early- and late-type galaxy deflectors are shown with continuous and dash-dotted lines, respectively. In both panels we indicate the typical value of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> for the <i>Gaia </i>survey and typical seeing-limited ground-based observations.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=4&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425411\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>We limited the redshift range to <span class=\"simple-math\">0 &lt;<i>z</i> &#8818; 4.5</span>. Although the spectro-photometric imaging of <i>Gaia </i>will enable detecting QSOs with a higher redshift, the limiting magnitude of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i> = 20</span> corresponds to very bright QSOs at redshift higher than <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 4.5</span>, which are very rare. </p>\n<p>The resulting <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq82.png\"></span> is shown in the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq84.png\"></span> plane in the left panel of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F3\">3</a>. The gray scale is proportional to the probability of detection, a darker gray indicating a higher probability of detection. For clarity, we indicate the magnitude cutoff of the survey <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i> = 20</span> as well as the brighter cutoff <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i> = 16</span> that was imposed because of the scarcity of such bright QSOs. For sources fainter than <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i> = 20</span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>d</i><sub>obs</sub></span> is null because the detection probability of these sources is assumed to be null. </p>\n<p>To assess the ability of the derived <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq82.png\"></span> to reproduce the observed properties of the real sources, we compared the DNCF <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq50.png\"></span> as a function of the apparent magnitude derived with Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD15\">15</a>) to observational sets that were used to determine the LF by applying the magnitude and redshift cuts of the observational samples to the joint probability density. </p>\n<p><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R26\">Richards et al. (2006)</a> have estimated the QSO DNCF in the SDSS <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i></span>-band on the basis of the SDSS-DR3 QSO catalog for sources restricted to the redshift ranges <span class=\"simple-math\">0.3 &lt;<i>z</i>&lt; 2.2</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">3 &lt;<i>z</i>&lt; 5</span>. In the lower redshift range, the survey is complete down to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i> &#8771; 19</span>. For the fainter magnitudes, we used the DNCF from the 2SQ/6QZ survey (also given in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R26\">Richards et al. 2006</a>). The different data sets are displayed in the right panel of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F3\">3</a>. </p>\n<p>We derived the DNCF from <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq82.png\"></span> through Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD13\">13</a>) by restricting the redshift range to <span class=\"simple-math\">0.3 &lt;<i>z</i>&lt; 2.2</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">3 &lt;<i>z</i>&lt; 5</span>. The results are shown in the right panel of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F3\">3</a> as continuous and dashed light gray curves. The simulated DNCF agree very well with the observational data. Following <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R26\">Richards et al. (2006)</a>, we used as definition of a QSO a source with an absolute magnitude in the continuum of the SDSS <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i></span>-band (with zero point at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 0</span>) brighter than <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;22.5</span>, considering a flat expanding universe with <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>H</i><sub>0</sub> = 70</span> km&#8201;s<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>-1</sup></span>&#8201;Mpc<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>-1</sup></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub> = 0.3</span>. In the same figure, we represent with a dark gray line the expected DNCF <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq163.png\"></span> of the entire <i>Gaia </i>population that we used in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD4\">4</a>) to calculate the amplification bias. </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"T1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/T1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 1</span></a><p>Comparison of the mean lensing optical depth and the expected number of detected multiply imaged quasars for different values of the survey angular resolution corresponding to a perfect survey (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0&#8242;&#8242;</span>), <i>Gaia </i>(<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span>), and typical ground-based observations (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.6&#8242;&#8242;</span>).</p>\n</div></div>\n        </p>\n<p>Combining Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD13\">13</a>) and (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD14\">14</a>), the normalization factor of the joint probability density is <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub><i>Gaia</i></sub>/<i>N</i><sub>QSO</sub></span>, that is, the number of QSOs detected per steradian, from which we may trivially derive the total number of QSOs expected to be detected in the survey. Considering that QSOs will be detectable over 60% of the sky (thus excluding the low galactic latitude fields), this leads to the expected detection of <span class=\"simple-math\">6.64 &#215; 10<sup>5</sup></span> sources brighter than <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i> = 20</span>. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R17\">Mignard (2012)</a> has estimated the surface density of QSOs brighter than <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i> = 20</span> and concluded that the <i>Gaia </i>survey should expect the discovery of 5.5 to <span class=\"simple-math\">7 &#215; 10<sup>5</sup></span> QSOs; this result agrees well with our own estimate. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R32\">Slezak (2007)</a> also previously estimated the number of QSOs to be detected: <span class=\"simple-math\">7.2 &#215; 10<sup>5</sup></span>. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S11\"></a>4. Results</h2>\n<p>We have computed the mean lensing optical depth <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i>&#10217;</span> for the whole population of QSOs by means of Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD16\">16</a>) for different values of the survey angular resolution <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> (i.e., the minimum image separation for which point-like sources with similar amplification may be distinguished). In Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD16\">16</a>), we alternatively considered the lensing optical depth <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#964;</i></span> for deflectors modeled as SIS (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#964;</i><sub>SIS</sub></span> in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD5\">5</a>)) and as SIE deflectors (Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD11\">11</a>)), considering the population of both early- and late-type galaxies. When considering SIE deflectors, we calculated both <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#964;</i><sub>SIE</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#964;</i><sub>SIE<i>,i</i></sub></span>. In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F4\">4</a> we represent as a function of the angular resolution <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> of the survey the dependence of the different average optical depths <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i><sub>SIS</sub>&#10217;</span>, <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i><sub>SIE</sub>&#10217;</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i><sub>SIE<i>,i</i></sub>&#10217;</span> and the evolution of the fraction of events with formation of three or four lensed images, that is, <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i><sub><i>SIE,</i>3</sub>&#10217;</span>/<span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i><sub>SIE</sub>&#10217;</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i><sub><i>SIE,</i>4</sub>&#10217;</span>/<span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i><sub>SIE</sub>&#10217;</span>, for both types of galaxy populations. </p>\n<p>The average total optical depths <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i><sub>SIS</sub>&#10217;</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i><sub>SIE</sub>&#10217;</span> show a very similar behavior: they both decrease as <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> increases because lensing events with images too close to each other are not resolved by the survey and are detected as single sources. In Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#T1\">1</a> we list the numerical values of the lensing optical depth for different values of the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> parameter, representative of a perfect survey (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0&#8242;&#8242;</span>), the <i>Gaia </i>survey (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span>), and seeing-limited ground-based observations (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.6&#8242;&#8242;</span>). <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> represents the smallest angular separation between two point-like sources with similar brightness for which the survey source detection procedure is capable to separate the two lensed images. We considered <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> to be independent of the relative brightness between the lensed images. This assumption is motivated by the fact that the regions contributing the most to the lensing cross sections are the most amplified (where the source is located inside and near the tangential caustics). For these configurations, the brighter and closer lensed images are located near the tangential critical curve and show similar amplification (see, e.g., <a name=\"InR29\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R29\">Schneider et al. 1992</a>, Chap. 6). For typical ground-based observations, we considered seeing-limited observations (typically <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span><span class=\"simple-math\">1&#8722;1.2&#8242;&#8242;</span>). With PSF-fitting techniques, we may at best resolve point-like images with the same brightness separated by half the PSF full width at half maximum, that is, by half of the seeing value. </p>\n<p>\n        \n        <a name=\"F5\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-fig5_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 5</span></a><p><i>Left</i>: expected normalized distributions <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i></span> as a function of the redshift of the lensed sources (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>s</sub></span>) and of the deflectors (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>d</sub></span>). For comparison, we also include the normalized redshift distribution of the sources (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub>QSO</sub></span>). The simulations were made assuming <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span>. We indicate the median value of each distribution (<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq215.png\"></span>, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq216.png\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq217.png\"></span>). <i>Right</i>: normalized distribution <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq110.png\"></span> of the lensed sources as a function of the apparent magnitude. For comparison, we show the DNCF as a function of the magnitude of all the detected sources, normalized by <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>N</i><sub>QSO</sub>/ &#937;<sub><i>Gaia</i></sub></span>.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=5&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425411\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n      </p>\n<p>For the early-type galaxy population, the average lensing optical depth for a perfect survey is <span class=\"simple-math\">3.994 &#215; 10<sup>-3</sup></span> (<span class=\"simple-math\">3.747 &#215; 10<sup>-3</sup></span> for the SIE lens model), and this is only a few percent lower for the <i>Gaia </i>survey, that is, <span class=\"simple-math\">3.917 &#215; 10<sup>-3</sup></span> (<span class=\"simple-math\">3.663 &#215; 10<sup>-3</sup></span>). For seeing-limited ground-based surveys, however, about one-third of the lensed sources are unresolved, with the mean lensing optical depth dropping to <span class=\"simple-math\">2.718 &#215; 10<sup>-3</sup></span>(<span class=\"simple-math\">2.431 &#215; 10<sup>-3</sup></span>). Considering the estimated number of <span class=\"simple-math\">6.64 &#215; 10<sup>5</sup></span> sources to be detected by the <i>Gaia </i>survey, there are thus 2653 (2490) expected lensed sources, out of which 2602 (2433) should be detected by the <i>Gaia </i>survey. On the other hand, the seeing-limited ground-based follow-up of the lensing events will only be possible for 1806 (1615) of these sources, unless adaptive optics observations are made possible using large telescopes. </p>\n<p>Although the late-type galaxy populations are more numerous, they are less efficient deflectors because of their lower mass. For the <i>Gaia </i>survey, the average lensing optical depth due to the late-type galaxy population is <span class=\"simple-math\">0.84 &#215; 10<sup>-3</sup></span> (<span class=\"simple-math\">0.68 &#215; 10<sup>-3</sup></span> for the SIE lens model), but because they tend to form lensing events with lensed images closer to one another, they represent a negligeable fraction for typical seeing-limited ground-based observations. This deflector population is expected to lead to the formation of 558 (453 for the SIE lens model) multiply imaged quasars. </p>\n<p>In conclusion, combining the expectation for the early- and late-type galaxy populations, the <i>Gaia </i>survey is expected to lead to the detection of 3160 (2886 for the SIE lens model) multiply imaged quasars. </p>\n<p>These results are consistent with a former simplified estimate of the number of gravitational lens systems to be detected by <i>Gaia </i>by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R4\">Finet et al. (2012)</a>, who found <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i>&#10217; = 5.9 &#215; 10<sup>-3</sup></span> for the SIS deflectors without taking into account the finite instrument resolution and considering only the population of early-type galaxies. The authors used a flat FLRW universe with <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub> = 0.27</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>H</i><sub>0</sub> = 72</span> km s<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>-1</sup></span> Mpc<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>-1</sup></span>. Considering the same universe model and a perfect instrument, we find <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i><sub>SIS</sub>&#10217; = 4.3 &#215; 10<sup>-3</sup></span>. The slight differences probably arise because they considered sources as bright as <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i> = 15</span> to be affected by a larger amplification bias and a redshift range up to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 5</span>, which slightly overestimates the very high redshift sources that have a higher optical depth. </p>\n<p><span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i><sub>SIS</sub>&#10217;</span>and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i><sub>SIE</sub>&#10217;</span> lead to a very similar estimate of the number of lensed sources to be detected and show a similar behavior as a function of the angular resolution parameter <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span>, as seen in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F4\">4</a>. Nevertheless, the SIS model leads to a lensing optical depth estimate about <span class=\"simple-math\">10</span>% higher than that of the SIE model. This is because the SIE mass distribution, initially introduced to conserve the projected mass inside iso-density curves with respect to the SIS case (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R14\">Kormann et al. 1994</a>), does not preserve the size of the geometrical cross section, that is, the area inside the caustics. For very elliptical deflectors, the geometrical cross section of the SIE deflector is smaller than that of the SIS because the radial caustic curve flattens when the ellipticity increases. Furthermore, the probability for a lensed source to have a given total amplification is different for the two mass distributions, thus leading to a different amplification bias effect (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R6\">Huterer et al. 2005</a>). </p>\n<p>Figure <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F4\">4</a> shows that of the gravitationally lensed sources, the configurations with two detected images are the most likely. Furthermore, the fraction of events with two lensed images increases as <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> increases, from 91.7% for a perfect survey to 94.8% for <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.6&#8242;&#8242;</span> (cfr Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#T1\">1</a>) for the early-type galaxy deflectors, because some configurations with three or four formed images have only two resolved images. We see a similar behavior for the results considering the late-type deflectors. We represent in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F4\">4</a> the evolution of the fraction of events with three or four detected lensed images as a function of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span>. From Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#T1\">1</a>, considering the early-type galaxy deflectors, we see that 204 lensed sources are expected to be composed of four lensed images (three with three lensed images), but because of the limited angular resolution of the satellite, only 134 (62) are expected to be detected with four (three) observable lensed images. Of these, 75 (9) lensing events with three (four) lensed images will be observable by means of seeing-limited ground-based observations, which will complement the times series and spectra acquired by the satellite. The late-type population is expected to lead to the formation of 57 events with more than two lensed images among the lensed sources in the <i>Gaia </i>survey, none of which could be detected in a seeing-limited ground-based survey. </p>\n<p>The lensed sources to be detected by the <i>Gaia </i>mission will thus constitute an unprecedented statistical sample, at least an order of magnitude larger than the existing ones, such as the ground-based SDSS Quasar Lens Search sample (62 lensed sources, 26 in the statistical sample, see <a name=\"InR7\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R7\">Inada et al. 2012</a>) or the 13 lenses from the CLASS statistical sample (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R1\">Browne et al. 2003</a>). </p>\n<p>In the left panel of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F5\">5</a>, we show the expected normalized redshift distributions of the lensed sources <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq230.png\"></span> and of the deflectors <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq231.png\"></span>. We computed these distributions using Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD17\">17</a>) and (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD18\">18</a>), assuming the typical angular resolution of <i>Gaia </i><span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span>. For the normalized deflector redshift distribution, we represent the expected distributions for the early- and the late-type deflector populations. For comparison, we represent the normalized redshift distribution of the sources (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub>QSO</sub></span>) obtained by integrating <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq82.png\"></span> over <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i></span>. As the latter is a normalized joint distribution, its marginal distribution <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub>QSO</sub></span> is normalized as well. </p>\n<p>\n        \n        <a name=\"F6\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-fig6_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 6</span></a><p><i>Left</i>: normalized redshift distribution of the deflectors <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq231.png\"></span> and its cumulative representation for three different values of the angular resolution <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0,0.2</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">0.6&#8242;&#8242;</span>. <i>Right</i>: cumulative distribution <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#964;</i><sup>-1</sup>d<i>&#964;</i></span>/d<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> as a function of the lens redshift. We show the case for two different source redshifts (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>s</sub> = 2</span> and 4) and three different values of the angular resolution parameter (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0,0.6</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">1&#8242;&#8242;</span>), modeling the deflectors by means of the SIS and SIE models.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=6&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425411\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n      </p>\n<p>We also indicate the median value of each distribution (<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq238.png\"></span>, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq239.png\"></span>, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq240.png\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq217.png\"></span>). We clearly observe a shift for the lensed population toward higher redshifts compared to the entire population of QSOs, with a distribution shifting from <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq241.png\"></span> to <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq242.png\"></span>. This is mainly explained by the increase in geometrical lensing volume with the source redshift, which introduces a favorable bias toward sources located farther away. The shape of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>s</sub></sub></span> is also influenced by the amplification bias, which in our case favors low-redshift sources. Because these sources have on average a brighter apparent magnitude (than those with a higher redshift), their amplification bias calculated through Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD4\">4</a>) is larger because of the steeper slope of the DNCF for these  magnitudes. </p>\n<p>The normalized redshift distributions of the deflectors are different for the early- and the late-type galaxy deflectors. For a perfect instrument (i.e., <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0&#8242;&#8242;</span>), these distributions would be identical, as demonstrated in Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#APP2\">B</a>. But in this simulation we considered <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span>. This excludes lensing events with lensed images whose image separation is too small. Therefore, the fraction of rejected lensing events is higher for the late-type galaxy population. Furthermore, for a given source redshift, the first lensing events to be rejected are those with a higher deflector redshift (because the Einstein angular radius scales as <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq243.png\"></span> ). This leads to a normalized deflector redshift distribution that peaks at lower redshift for the late-type galaxy population. </p>\n<p>The normalized distributions as a function of redshift of the lensed sources <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq230.png\"></span> and of the deflectors <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq231.png\"></span> show no dependence on the chosen deflector model: both the SIS and SIE models lead to exactly the same distributions. Furthermore, the normalized redshift distribution of the lensed sources <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq230.png\"></span> is identical when considering early- or late-type galaxy populations. </p>\n<p>In the right panel of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F5\">5</a> we illustrate the normalized distribution <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq110.png\"></span> of the lensed sources as a function of their apparent magnitude computed from Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD19\">19</a>) for the SIS lens model. For comparison, we show the DNCF as a function of magnitude of all the detected sources, normalized by <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>N</i><sub>QSO</sub>/ &#937;<sub><i>Gaia</i></sub></span>, the number of sources detected per solid angle in the magnitude range <span class=\"simple-math\">16 &lt;<i>m</i>&lt; 20</span>. The distribution of the lensed sources presents an excess of brighter sources, benefiting from the amplification bias. In our simulations, we found no effect of the angular resolution <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> on <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq110.png\"></span>. Neither did we find differences between the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>m</i></sub></span> distributions when considering the early- and late-type deflector populations. </p>\n<p>We now analyze the effect of the finite instrumental resolution on these different distributions. We showed that modeling the deflectors by means of the SIE and SIS mass distributions leads to exactly the same normalized distributions <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq230.png\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq231.png\"></span>, therefore we only considered the SIS deflectors in the remaining part to minimize the computation time. In the left panel of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F6\">6</a> we display the normalized distribution of the deflectors <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq231.png\"></span> and its cumulative function as a function of the deflector redshift for three different values of the angular resolution <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> corresponding to the perfect instrument case, the <i>Gaia </i>mission, and typical ground-based observations. </p>\n<p>The normalized and cumulative distributions corresponding to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0&#8242;&#8242;</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span> look similar. When compared to the ground-based observations (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.6&#8242;&#8242;</span>), we conclude that the effect of the loss in resolution power is to miss the lensing events with a deflector at higher redshift. This may be easily understood for the SIS case. An SIS deflector produces two lensed images separated by an angle equal to twice the Einstein angle <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub></span>. From the definition of the Einstein angle in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD2\">2</a>), <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub></span> scales as <a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq246.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(27)</span></span>For a source at a redshift <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>s</sub></span>, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq247.png\"></span> is a decreasing function of the deflector redshift, consequently, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub></span> decreases as the deflector redshift <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>d</sub></span> increases, which will produce lensing events with images closer to each other, the first to be discarded as <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> increases. </p>\n<p>\n        \n        <a name=\"F7\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-fig7_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 7</span></a><p><i>Left:</i> average optical depth <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i>&#10217;</span> (considering all deflector types) as a function of cosmological matter density parameter <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span>, modeling the deflectors with the SIS and SIE models. <i>Right: </i>normalized redshift distributions <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>s</sub></sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>d</sub></sub></span> of the lensed sources and of the deflectors (for the early-type galaxy population) for different values of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub> = 0,0.3</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">1</span>. All simulations were produced for <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span>.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=7&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425411\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n      </p>\n<p>We now consider the cumulative distribution as a function of the deflector redshifts. For simplicity, we only considered here the early-type galaxy population. For the ground-based observations, 90% of the observed lensed sources have a deflector with a redshift lower than <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 0.88</span>. Most of the studies of the evolution effect in the deflector population based on lensing statistics are compatible with a no-evolution scenario or very little evolution of the deflectors (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R20\">Oguri &amp; Marshall 2010</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R2\">Chae 2010</a>; and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R22\">Oguri et al. 2012</a>). But it is very inefficient to use ground-based observations (from which most of the statistical samples of lenses are issued) to study the evolution of the deflector population because they cut out all lens systems with a deflector at high redshift and are thus only suitable for studying the low-redshift population (typically, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i>&lt; 0.88</span>). </p>\n<p>For the <i>Gaia </i>mission, <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>30% of the detected lenses that are due to the early-type galaxy population will have a deflector at a redshift higher than <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i>&gt; 0.88</span>, that is, <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>800 lenses assuming the 2433 lenses to be detected, and <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>240 lensed sources will have a deflector in the redshift range <span class=\"simple-math\">1.27 &lt;<i>z</i><sub>d</sub>&lt; 2</span>. The statistical sample of lenses to be unveiled by the <i>Gaia </i>mission will thus provide a sample that is very well suited for the evolution study of the population of early- and late-type galaxies at high redshift because of both the very large number of sources and the high angular resolution power with which the lensed sources are detected. </p>\n<p>We also computed the normalized distribution <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq230.png\"></span> of the lensed sources as a function of redshift for different values of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span>. The angular resolution parameter <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> has no effect at all on <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq230.png\"></span>. This implies that the relative decrease in the lensing optical depth due to an increase in <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> is independent of the source redshift and absolute magnitude. To understand this, we computed the cumulative distribution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>d&#964;</i>/<i>d</i><i>z</i><sub>d</sub></span> normalized to the source optical depth for a perfect survey, that is, <a name=\"FD28\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq255.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(28)</span></span>The behavior of the cumulative distribution in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD28\">28</a>) as a function of redshift is shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F6\">6</a>. We show two different sources at redshift <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>s</sub> = 2</span> and 4, considering three different angular resolutions <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0,0.6</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">1&#8242;&#8242;</span>, and modeling the deflector with both the SIS and SIE deflectors. For clarity, we do not show the case for <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span>. </p>\n<p>We first consider <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0&#8242;&#8242;</span> (shown as a black dashed line). For this case, the normalized cumulative distributions are identical for the SIS and SIE cases. Because the distributions corresponding to the different <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>s</sub></span> differ, the differential contribution to the lensing optical depth is different for the two sources. Nevertheless, for the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.6&#8242;&#8242;</span> instrumental resolution we observe that the fraction of the optical depth lost due to an increase in <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> is the same for <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>s</sub> = 2</span> and 4 for both the SIS and SIE cases. The fraction of the optical depth lost due to an increase in <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> is thus independent of redshift, or in other words, the ratio <a name=\"FD29\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq258.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(29)</span></span>is independent of the source redshift. We computed the same distribution for sources with different apparent magnitudes and found no effect of the source magnitude on the distribution in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD28\">28</a>). </p>\n<p>As a consequence, the behavior as a function of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> of the average optical depth <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i>&#10217;</span> can be computed by considering a perfect instrument and calculating the ratio in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD29\">29</a>) for a source with a randomly chosen redshift and magnitude. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S12\"></a>4.1. Effect of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span>\n</h3>\n<p>In the left panel of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F7\">7</a> we show the evolution of the average lensing optical depth <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i>&#10217;</span> as a function of the cosmological matter density parameter <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span>, assuming a flat FLRW universe and considering the finite angular resolution <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span> corresponding to the <i>Gaia </i>survey. We observe a very high dependence of the average optical depth as a function of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> with an order of magnitude difference between an empty universe and a universe full of matter (<span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub> = 0</span> and 1, respectively). For this reason, using the fraction of lensed sources in a sample of sources has been proposed by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R34\">Turner et al. (1984)</a> to constrain the value of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span>. </p>\n<p>The observed behavior agrees very well when modeling the deflectors by means of the SIS and SIE deflectors, although the SIS model always slightly overestimates the lensing optical depth. </p>\n<p>In our simulations for the SIE deflector, we observed no dependence as a function of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> of the relative fraction of lensing events on a given number of lensed images. </p>\n<p>In the right panel of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F7\">7</a> we show the expected normalized redshift distribution of the lensed sources <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq261.png\"></span> and of the deflectors <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq262.png\"></span> for the three different values of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub> = 0,0.3</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">1</span>. For the sake of clarity, we only show the deflector redshift distribution corresponding to the early-type galaxy population, but the one associated with the late-type population presents a similar behavior. As previously mentioned, the obtained normalized redshift distributions <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>s</sub></sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>d</sub></sub></span> are identical for the SIS and SIE models. To minimize the computing time, we present the distributions obtained for the SIS model case. </p>\n<p>Finally, in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F8\">8</a> we represent the normalized distribution <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub></sub></span> as a function of Einstein angle <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub></span> of the lensed sources for different values of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span>. These distributions were obtained with the help of Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD23\">23</a>). We considered the deflectors to be modeled with SIS deflectors and an angular resolution <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span> corresponding to the <i>Gaia </i>survey. We find a very small dependence of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq264.png\"></span> on the cosmological model parameter value. </p>\n<p>We also computed the normalized distribution <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq110.png\"></span> as a function of apparent magnitude <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>m</i></span> and found no effect of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span>. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F8\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-fig8_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 8</span></a><p>Effect of the cosmological matter density parameter <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> on the normalized Einstein angular radius distribution <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq264.png\"></span> of the lensed sources. We considered the deflectors to be modeled by SIS deflectors and an angular resolution <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span> corresponding to the <i>Gaia </i>survey. <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub></span> is expressed in arcsecond.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=8&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425411\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S13\"></a>5. Conclusions</h2>\n<p>Of the <span class=\"simple-math\">6.64 &#215; 10<sup>5</sup></span> QSOs that are brighter than <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i> = 20</span> to be detected in the <i>Gaia </i>survey, we expect about 2886 to be multiply imaged sources and that 450 of these are produced by a late-type galaxy. We have modeled the deflector population by means of the SIE and SIS mass distributions and found both model predictions to agree very well, although the SIS model overestimates the mean lensing optical depth by <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span><span class=\"simple-math\">10%</span>. Most of the multiply imaged sources will be composed of two images, but we expect more than 250 lensed sources with more than two lensed images detected. </p>\n<p>We expect only <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>1600 of the multiply imaged quasars to have an angular separation between their images that is large enough to be resolved from seeing-limited observations (i.e., considering a ground-based survey without an adaptive optics system), allowing the acquisition of ground-based data to complement the spectra and time series provided by the satellite, <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>80 of them having more than two lensed images detected. </p>\n<p>We showed that lenses with a deflector at high redshift tend to be missed as the angular resolution of a survey becomes worse because these events are characterized by a smaller Einstein angular radius. Thanks to its angular resolution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span>, the lensed sources discovered in the <i>Gaia </i>survey will thus provide a unique statistical sample of lensed sources from which to study the evolution effects of the deflecting galaxy population, with the detection of <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>800 lenses at a redshift between <span class=\"simple-math\">0.8</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">2</span>. </p>\n<p>We did not consider the influence of the deflector environment, which may produce an additional shear and convergence to the gravitational potential. <a name=\"InR21\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R21\">Oguri et al. (2005)</a> have shown that the additional convergence produced by the galaxy environment may increase the lensing probability (especially at large angular separation) by boosting the image separation and amplification bias, mainly driven by convergence. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R6\">Huterer et al. (2005)</a> showed that the external shear increases the fraction of quads in a sample of lensed sources. Our estimate of the number of lenses to be discovered by <i>Gaia </i>may thus slightly underestimate the lenses and quads to be discovered. We also neglected multiple deflectors at different redhshifts because the probability for such an event would be on the order of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i>&#10217;<sup>2</sup> ~ 10<sup>-5</sup></span>, which is negligible compared to the lensing probability by a single deflector. </p>\n<p>We computed the normalized redshift distributions of the lensed sources <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>s</sub></sub></span> and of the deflectors <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>d</sub></sub></span> and found that these normalized distributions are the same whether the deflectors are modeled by means of the SIS or the SIE mass distributions. The normalized deflector redshift distribution expected for the late-type galaxy population peaks at a higher redshift than that for the early-type one. </p>\n<p>Furthermore, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>s</sub></sub></span> is independent of the angular resolution of the survey. As a consequence, we conclude that the fraction of the optical depth lost by a source when increasing <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub></span> is independent of source redshift. </p>\n<p>Finally, we analyzed the effect of the cosmological matter density parameter <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> on the average lensing optical depth and on the distributions as a function of the redshift of the lensed sources and deflectors. We conclude that all three are sensitive to the cosmological model parameter value and may be used to constrain the cosmological model. We found no effect of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> on the fraction of lensed sources as a function of the number of lensed images or on the apparent magnitude distribution of the lensed sources. </p>\n    <hr width=\"30%\" align=\"left\">\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN2\"></a><sup>1</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">\n          <a href=\"http://sci.esa.int/gaia/\" target=\"_blank\">http://sci.esa.int/gaia/</a>\n        </p>\n</div></div>\n    <h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"ref\"></a>References</h2>\n    <div id=\"content\">\n        <ol class=\"references\">\n                    <li>\n                <a name=\"R1\"></a>Browne, I.
