E., Richards, G. T., Bauer, A., et al. 2001, AJ, 122, 549\n\n                \n                                                            <a target=\"link_edps\" href=\"https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/#abs/2001AJ....122..549V/abstract\">\n                                                    [NASA ADS]\n                                                </a>\n                                                                                <a target=\"link_edps\" href=\"https://doi.org/10.1086/321167\">\n                                                    [CrossRef]\n                                                </a>\n                                    \n                \n                                    <a href=\"https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?author=Vanden+Berk%2C+D.+E.%2C+Richards%2C+G.+T.%2C+Bauer%2C+A.&journal=AJ&volume=122&issue=2&pages=549&publication_year=2001&issn=00046256\">[Google&nbsp;Scholar]</a>\n                \n                \n                 <span class=\"Z3988\" title=\"\">\n                                    </span>\n\n                \n                            </li>\n                </ol>\n    </div>\n\n    \n      <h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"app\"></a>Appendix A:  <i>Gaia G</i>-band K-correction and magnitude conversion</h2>\n<p>We here describe the different relations used to convert absolute magnitudes between the <i>Gaia </i>and the SDSS photometric systems. </p>\n<p>We followed <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R26\">Richards et al. (2006)</a> and express the absolute magnitudes <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i></span> in the <i>Gaia </i><span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band as magnitudes of the continuum, with a zero point of the continuum K-correction at redshift <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 2</span>. <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i></span> is thus defined by <a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq269.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(A.1)</span></span>where <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>K</i><sub>em</sub></span> is the contribution from the emission lines and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>K</i><sub>cont<i>,z</i> = 2</sub></span> the continuum K-correction with zero point at redshift <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 2</span>. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F9\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-fig9_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. A.1</span></a><p>K-correction in the <i>Gaia </i>photometric <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band as a function of redshift. We represent the total K-correction (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>K</i></span>) with zero point of the continuum contribution at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 2</span>, the continuum contributions with zero points at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 0</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 2</span> (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>K</i><sub>cont</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>K</i><sub>cont<i>,z</i> = 2</sub></span>), and the emission line contribution (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>K</i><sub><i>em</i></sub></span>).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=9&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425411\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>To estimate the K-correction of the <i>Gaia </i>photometric <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band, we computed the correlation between the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band spectral transmission function (in terms of wavelengths) with the QSO synthetic spectrum derived from SDSS QSO spectra by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R35\">Vanden Berk et al. (2001)</a>. The synthetic spectrum ranging from 3800 to <span class=\"simple-math\">9200 &#197;</span> could not cover the entire wavelength range of the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span> filter (<span class=\"simple-math\">3210&#8722;11020 &#197;</span> in the observer comoving reference frame). Because the synthetic spectrum was well fitted by a continuum spectrum with spectral index <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub> = &#8722;0.46</span> between the Ly-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i></span> and H<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i></span> lines, and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub> = &#8722;1.58</span> for wavelengths longer than the H<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i></span> line (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R35\">Vanden Berk et al. 2001</a>), we extrapolated the synthetic spectrum toward longer wavelengths assuming a continuum spectrum with spectral index <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub> = &#8722;1.58</span>. </p>\n<p>We computed the contribution of the continuum to the K-correction assuming a break in the spectral index, considering the zero points of the K-Correction at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 0</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 2</span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>K</i><sub>cont</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>K</i><sub>cont<i>,z</i> = 2</sub></span>, respectively. The behavior of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>K</i><sub>cont<i>,z</i> = 2</sub></span> as a function of redshift is displayed in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F9\">A.1</a>. </p>\n<p>Finally, the contribution to the apparent magnitude of the emission lines <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>K</i><sub>em</sub></span> is given by <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>K</i><sub>em</sub> = <i>K</i>&#8722;<i>K</i><sub>cont<i>,z</i> = 2</sub></span>. The computed K-correction is shown as a function of redshift in  Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F9\">A.1</a>. </p>\n<p>To convert the absolute magnitudes <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub><i>i</i></sub></span> from the SDSS <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i></span>-band to the <i>Gaia </i><span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band absolute magnitude <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i></span>, we used the K-correction for the SDSS <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i></span>-band given in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R26\">Richards et al. (2006)</a>, the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band K-correction previously described, and calculated an average apparent magnitude transformation between the <i>Gaia </i><span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-magnitude and SDSS-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i></span> magnitude as follows: <a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq281.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(A.2)</span></span>where <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq282.png\"></span> is the synthetic QSO spectrum from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R35\">Vanden Berk et al. (2001)</a>, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq283.png\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq284.png\"></span> are the spectral transmission of the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i></span> bands, considering both magnitudes in the AB-magnitude system. The behavior of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq145.png\"></span> as a function of redshift is shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F10\">A.2</a>. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F10\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-fig10_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. A.2</span></a><p>Average color transformation <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq145.png\"></span> as a function of QSO redshift assuming the source spectral type to be that of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R35\">Vanden Berk et al. (2001)</a> and both magnitude systems to be AB-magnitudes.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=10&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425411\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>The absolute magnitude average transformation is given by <a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq285.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(A.3)</span></span>where <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq286.png\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq287.png\"></span> are the K-corrections in the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>- and SDSS <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i></span>-band, respectively. </p>\n      <h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"app\"></a>Appendix B:  <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>d</sub></sub></span> dependence on the deflector type</h2>\n<p>In this appendix, we demonstrate that <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>d</sub></sub></span> is independent of the deflector type under the assumption of constant deflector comoving density and a perfect instrument. For simplicity, we consider the case of deflectors modeled by an SIS mass distribution. </p>\n<p>The expression of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#964;</i><sub>SIS</sub></span> in Eq. (8) can be further developed by inserting the expression of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq289.png\"></span> which, using the definition of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub></span> in Eq. (2) and that of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#931;<sub>SIS</sub></span> in Eq. (3), may be written as <a name=\"FD33\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq290.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(B.1)</span></span>Inserting the latter expression into Eq. (8) leads to <a name=\"FD34\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq291.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(B.2)</span></span>where we defined <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq292.png\"></span>. The coefficient in brackets includes all the dependence on the parameters describing the VDFs (<span class=\"simple-math\">&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub>,<i>&#963;</i><sub>&#8727;</sub><i>,&#945;,&#946;</i></span>), which may refer to either early- or late-type galaxies. In our development, the deflector comoving density is assumed constant, therefore the VDF parameters do not depend on the redshift. </p>\n<p>We may obtain an expression for <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq294.png\"></span> by differentiating the former expression of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#964;</i><sub>SIS</sub></span> with respect to the deflector redshift <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span>. The result is <a name=\"FD35\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq295.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(B.3)</span></span>For a perfect instrument, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#964;</i><sub>SIS</sub></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq296.png\"></span> depend in an identical way on the VDF parameters, shown in the first factor of Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD34\">B.2</a>) and (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD35\">B.3</a>). Therefore, when calculating the normalized redshift  </p>\n<p>distribution of the deflectors by inserting Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD34\">B.2</a>) and (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#FD35\">B.3</a>) into the definition of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>d</sub></sub></span> (Eq. (18)) and using the definition of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216;<i>&#964;</i>&#10217;</span> (Eq. (16)), the factors containing the VDF parameters cancel each other out as long as we assume no redshift or absolute magnitude dependence of the VDF parameters. For a perfect instrument, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#969;</i><sub><i>z</i><sub>d</sub></sub></span> is thus identical for early- and late-type galaxy deflectors because it does no longer depend on the parameters defining the deflector VDF (<span class=\"simple-math\">&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub>,<i>&#963;</i><sub>&#8727;</sub><i>,&#945;,</i></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i></span>). </p>\n<p>However, when the finite angular resolution of the survey is taken into account, the integration area for the lensing cross section <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>S</i><sub><i>y</i></sub></span> is now a function of the ratio <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub>/<i>&#952;</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span>, with <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq299.png\"></span>. This dependence on <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> leads to different results for the two deflector types because this parameter differs for the early- and late-type galaxy VDF. </p>\n    \n  <h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"tabs\"></a>All Tables</h2>\n<div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/T1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 1</span></a><p>Comparison of the mean lensing optical depth and the expected number of detected multiply imaged quasars for different values of the survey angular resolution corresponding to a perfect survey (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0&#8242;&#8242;</span>), <i>Gaia </i>(<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span>), and typical ground-based observations (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i><sub>min</sub> = 0.6&#8242;&#8242;</span>).</p>\n<div class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#T1\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"figs\"></a>All Figures</h2>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-fig1_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 1</span></a><p>Luminosity function as a function of the absolute magnitude <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub><i>i</i></sub></span> in the SDSS <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i></span>-band for different redshift bins. We have included the LF determined by <a name=\"InR25\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R25\">Richards et al. (2005)</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#R23\">Palanque-Delabrouille et al. (2013)</a> (converted to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub><i>i</i></sub></span> magnitude). The different fitted models correspond to no contraints on the redshift behavior of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub></span> (dashed light gray line), to an evolution model for <span class=\"simple-math\">&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> is fitted freely (light gray line), and to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub></span> both constrained by an evolution model (continuous black line). The latter is the final evolution model chosen for the simulations, see main text for the full description.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=1&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425411\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F1\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 2</span></a><p>Behavior of the LF <span class=\"simple-math\">&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> parameters as a function of the QSO redshift. The dark continuous line shows the fit model used in our simulations. The light gray markers show the best fit parameters for <span class=\"simple-math\">&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> when fitting the LF separately in each redshift bin, without any evolution model constraints. When constraining the evolution of the characteristic density, the best parameters are found to be <span class=\"simple-math\">log&#8201;&#934;<sub>&#8727; ,low<i>z</i></sub> = &#8722;5.85</span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>&#934;<sub>&#8727;</sub></sub> = &#8722;0.77 &#177; 0.31,</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>ref</sub> = 2.09 &#177; 0.28</span>.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=2&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425411\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14.html#F2\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-fig3_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 3</span></a><p><i>Left</i>: joint probability density <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/06/aa25411-14/aa25411-14-eq82.png\"></span> for the <i>Gaia </i>sources, derived using the LF evolution model described in the text. <i>Right</i>: DNCF as a function of the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>G</i></span>-band magnitude.
